DialogueOption.Text: I heard you delayed your launch date several times! Why’s that?

Dialogue.Page: Ah, I’m guessing you heard about this from Mica?
I hope you didn’t take too long to take off, or they’ll be telling future space cadets about how you delayed your launch for generations to come too, hah!
As I've told them many times.. The reason I delayed my launch date was because sand on Ember Twin was flowing to and filling up Ash Twin at the time.
Since I was hoping to explore Ash Twin on my first trip, the sand burying it would’ve made exploring anything rather hard!
That’s why I opted to delay my launch - though more times than I'd have liked - until the sand began to flow back to Ember Twin.

DialogueOption.Text: The sand flows back to Ash Twin?

Dialogue.Page: Indeed! I once spotted some tall Nomai structures on Ash Twin's surface we had never noticed before, while stargazing back on Timber Hearth. It seemed like a promising place to explore on my first trip!
From what I could tell, the structures appeared to be for stargazing. Each one had windows in their roofs that allowed you to peer out and see the planets and stars.
I must say, it was quite heartwarming to learn the Nomai shared my love for the stars!
I looked around for a while - but at some point, I realized the sand column had sucked my ship with it back to Ember Twin!
I had to cut my expedition short to make a distress call back to the village, and call Slate to pick me up. <Pause> ..I think he was more worried about my ship than me, though.
Since sand is flowing from Ash Twin to Ember Twin right now, why not check out Ash Twin for yourself, once a little more of its sand drains off?
You should be able to glean much more about what these structures than I did, especially with that new translator tool of yours. Just be careful where you leave your ship!

DialogueOption.Text: I already did! Those are Nomai warp towers that connect to the other planets.
Tell me more about the Twins' shifting sands!

Dialogue.Page: Why, yes! Haven’t you noticed before?
Right now, sand is flowing from Ash Twin to Ember Twin - but did you know the process eventually reverses? If you wait, you’ll see it eventually flows back to Ash Twin!
We're not completely sure why the sand flows back and forth between the Twins, but it seems to be a natural phenomena.
Even stranger, the process seems to happen in very precise intervals.. It's been consistent every time we've measured it. It's terribly fascinating!

DialogueOption.Text: How long do you think it'd take for sand to start flowing back to Ash Twin again?

Dialogue.Page: Gladly!
Right now, sand is flowing from Ash Twin to Ember Twin - but did you know the process eventually reverses? If you wait, you’ll see it eventually flows back to Ash Twin!
We're not completely sure why the sand flows back and forth between the Twins, but it seems to be a natural phenomena.
Even stranger, the process seems to happen in very precise intervals.. It's been consistent every time we've measured it. It's terribly fascinating!

DialogueOption.Text: How long do you think it'd take for sand to start flowing back to Ash Twin again?

Dialogue.Page: Hm... It will take a while longer, I believe.
Come back once more of the sand has drained off from Ash Twin, and I might be able to give you a more precise answer then!
If you’re feeling impatient, feel free to take a nap by the campfire to pass the time.
I have set up this camp here to avoid the sand column's path - so you need not worry about the sand column wandering this way while you rest.

DialogueOption.Text: Cool, cool. Tell me about what you found on Ash Twin, though!

Dialogue.Page: Goodness! That's right, that's what we were discussing at first, wasn't it? My apologies for rambling!
I once spotted some tall Nomai structures on Ash Twin's surface we had never noticed before, while stargazing back on Timber Hearth. It seemed like a promising place to explore on my first trip!
From what I could tell, the structures appeared to be for stargazing. Each one had windows in their roofs that allowed you to peer out and see the planets and stars.
I must say, it was quite heartwarming to learn the Nomai shared my love for the stars!

I had to cut my expedition short to make a distress call back to the village, and call Slate to pick me up. <Pause> ..I think he was more worried about my ship than me, though.
Since sand is flowing from Ash Twin to Ember Twin right now, why not check out Ash Twin for yourself, once a little more of its sand drains off?
You should be able to glean much more about what these structures than I did, especially with that new translator tool of yours. Just be careful where you leave your ship!

DialogueOption.Text: I already did! Those are warp towers that the Nomai used to travel to the other planets.

Dialogue.Page: Goodness! That's what those towers are?! How.. how could I have missed that?
This does sound quite plausible.. The model ship and the Little Scouts do utilize some kind of Nomai warp technology that lets us warp them back to a fixed point, don't they?
Oh, a Nomai warp system right under our noses... If I had been more observant, our space program might be revolutionized by now!
But, you said that the Nomai used these "warp towers" to travel around their settlements across the star system easily, yes?
There are Nomai ruins on Timber Hearth as well - so could there be a "warp tower" that connects to Timber Hearth as well?
And if so, where would you arrive on Timber Hearth?

DialogueOption.Text: There is! One of the warp towers travels to the Nomai Ruins outside the village, but..

Dialogue.Page: Oh, hatchling! Imagine how much easier space travel would be for the space program, if this warp system connected us back to Timber Hearth!
I would love nothing more than to go investigate for myself while the sand is flowing from Ash Twin.. but I must focus on finishing these star charts first!
Would you kindly investigate in my stead? I shall catch up with you as soon as I finish my work here.
Oh, what terrific news!
..What's that? <Pause> There's GHOST MATTER on the arrival point?!
(sigh) What terrific news... Oh, how frustrating..
I suppose until we find a way around ghost matter - or, more likely, that patch of ghost matter evaporates with time - the space program will be stuck flying Slate's "spaceworthy" ships...
